name: property rights
description: Property rights entail the exclusive authority to determine how and by whom a particular resource is used.

clips.name: The Engagement
clips.description: Elaine's neighbor's dog keep Elaine awake at night barking.  She, Kramer, and Newman devise a scheme to kidnap the dog and move it to the country so it no longer bothers her.

tags.name: externality
tags.description: An externality is a situation in which the private costs or benefits to the producers or purchasers of a good or service differs from the total social costs or benefits entailed in its production and consumption. An externality exists whenever one individual's actions affect the well-being of another individual -- whether for the better (positive externality) or for the worse (negative externality).

tags.name: incentives
tags.description: An incentive is any factor (financial or non-financial) that enables or motivates a particular course of action, or counts as a reason for preferring one choice to the alternatives.

tags.name: property rights
tags.description: Property rights entail the exclusive authority to determine how and by whom a particular resource is used.

source.title: Seinfeld
source.description: Seinfeld ran for nine seasons on NBC and became famous as a “show about nothing.” Basically, the show allows viewers to follow the antics of Jerry, George, Elaine, and Kramer as they move through their daily lives, often encountering interesting people or dealing with special circumstances. It is the simplicity of Seinfeld that makes it so appropriate for use in economics courses. Using these clips (as well as clips from other television shows or movies) makes economic concepts come alive, making them more real for students. Ultimately, students will start seeing economics everywhere – in other TV shows, in popular music, and most importantly, in their own lives.

clips.name: The Parking Space
clips.description: George won't pay for a parking spot in a garage because he would rather find a public spot (nonexcludable) for free.  George backs into a spot while another guy comes in headfirst, resulting in the question, “Who is entitled to the space?”  Insecure property rights have led to overuse and conflict.  George says, “I was here first.”   The parking jam-up ruins street access for everyone else; everyone ends up fighting about property rights, even the police, who can't decide.

tags.name: common resource
tags.description: A common resource is a type of good consisting of a natural or human-made resource system, whose size or characteristics makes it costly, but not impossible, to exclude potential beneficiaries from obtaining benefits from its use. Unlike pure public goods, common resources face problems of congestion or overuse, because they are rival. Examples of common resources include irrigation systems, fishing grounds, pastures, forests, water or the atmosphere.

tags.name: non-excludable goods
tags.description: A non-excludable good is one for which it is impossible to prevent an individual who does not pay for that thing from enjoying the benefits of it.

tags.name: property rights
tags.description: Property rights entail the exclusive authority to determine how and by whom a particular resource is used.

tags.name: rival goods
tags.description: Rival goods are goods whose consumption by one consumer prevents simultaneous consumption by other consumers.

source.title: Seinfeld
source.description: Seinfeld ran for nine seasons on NBC and became famous as a “show about nothing.” Basically, the show allows viewers to follow the antics of Jerry, George, Elaine, and Kramer as they move through their daily lives, often encountering interesting people or dealing with special circumstances. Using these clips (as well as clips from other television shows or movies) makes economic concepts come alive, making them more real for students. Ultimately, students will start seeing economics everywhere – in other TV shows, in popular music, and most importantly, in their own lives.
